questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL : SOFTWARE ENGINEERING (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)"  ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN.  (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN.  (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is the primary responsibility of the marketing team at a software company?
question_texts: Which of the following is the primary responsibility of the marketing team at a software company?

options.option_text: To communicate with users and create prototypes.
To conduct market research to identify potential customers.
To analyze data generated from various teams and users in order to assist theorganization in making better decisions.
To address and resolve issues that clients encounter.

questions.question_text_1: In the scrum framework, which role is responsible to keep track of all the activities of a given sprint and ensuring that all the activities are completed successfully?
question_texts: In the scrum framework, which role is responsible to keep track of all the activities of a given sprint and ensuring that all the activities are completed successfully?

questions.question_text_1: Consider a software module in which all the functions refer to or update the same data structure.  Identify the type of cohesion the given module has.
question_texts: Consider a software module in which all the functions refer to or update the same data structure.  Identify the type of cohesion the given module has.

question_texts: Which of the following diagrams models the flow of control among computational activities?

questions.question_text_1: During debugging, a developer finds out the event that trigger incorrect behavior. He follows data control flow ahead until incorrect state reached.  Which of the following debugging strategies was chosen by the developer?
question_texts: During debugging, a developer finds out the event that trigger incorrect behavior. He follows data control flow ahead until incorrect state reached.  Which of the following debugging strategies was chosen by the developer?

questions.question_text_1: Which type of deployment environment is also known as the live environment where all the users can interact with the deployed system?
question_texts: Which type of deployment environment is also known as the live environment where all the users can interact with the deployed system?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is considered as the primary objective of caching to enhance performance of web applications?
question_texts: Which of the following is considered as the primary objective of caching to enhance performance of web applications?

options.option_text: It stores the results of common operations in memory.
It executes time consuming tasks outside the HTTP request-response cycle.
It can be used to analyze page resources, find optimization suggestions, checkSEO and accessibility metrics and calculate your performance score.

questions.question_text_1: In which of the software deployment strategies the users are allowed to choose the versions of software they want to use?
question_texts: In which of the software deployment strategies the users are allowed to choose the versions of software they want to use?

questions.question_text_1: Suppose you are creating a prototype for a web application using tools like Photoshop and PowerPoint.  In the above case, identify the type of prototype technique you have chosen.
question_texts: Suppose you are creating a prototype for a web application using tools like Photoshop and PowerPoint.  In the above case, identify the type of prototype technique you have chosen.

questions.question_text_1: Consider a scenario where a bus company has decided not to allow seat bookings for their bus more than three months in advance. As a result, on their bus booking website, the UI does not allow you to select a booking date that is more than three months away. Which of the following heuristics for UI evaluation does the app satisfy?
question_texts: Consider a scenario where a bus company has decided not to allow seat bookings for their bus more than three months in advance. As a result, on their bus booking website, the UI does not allow you to select a booking date that is more than three months away. Which of the following heuristics for UI evaluation does the app satisfy?

questions.question_text_1: Consider an EdTech company that decided to develop an educational portal based on GenAI services. To collect requirements for the proposed development, the company needs to gather responses from a very large group of users who are largely spread all over the world. Which of the following requirement gathering techniques will be most suitable in the given scenario?
question_texts: Consider an EdTech company that decided to develop an educational portal based on GenAI services. To collect requirements for the proposed development, the company needs to gather responses from a very large group of users who are largely spread all over the world. Which of the following requirement gathering techniques will be most suitable in the given scenario?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the SMART characteristics of user stories specifies that the story must provide business value to one or more stakeholders?
question_texts: Which of the SMART characteristics of user stories specifies that the story must provide business value to one or more stakeholders?

questions.question_text_1: A software company has developed and released a job portal that allows job seekers to apply for different organizations at different positions. Following its release, the company received numerous complaints stating that the website generates an internal server error when an applicant enters 0 in the experience field. The software company has decided to correct the problem. Identify the phase in which the correction has to be made.
question_texts: A software company has developed and released a job portal that allows job seekers to apply for different organizations at different positions. Following its release, the company received numerous complaints stating that the website generates an internal server error when an applicant enters 0 in the experience field. The software company has decided to correct the problem. Identify the phase in which the correction has to be made.

questions.question_text_1: Consider a mobile app that enables users to send and receive music files and audio messages directly from each other. Users exchange music files and audio messages without the need for a centralized server.  What kind of software architecture does the mobile app most likely use?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are the benefit(s) of using knowledge sharing tools?
question_texts: Which of the following is/are the benefit(s) of using knowledge sharing tools?

options.option_text: It helps to document and archive the knowledge of one project that might berequired in some other project.
It helps all members of the team to get a big picture as well as detailed view ofprogress.
It helps in easy migration of developers between different projects.
It helps the developers to become more productive by using tools like IDEs.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are true about the staging environment of deployment?
question_texts: Which of the following is/are true about the staging environment of deployment?

options.option_text: It is also known as pre-production environment.
It is also known as live environment where all the users can interact with thedeployed system.
It is the local environment for individual developers that provides IDEs andother tools.
It exactly resembles the production environment, and it runs on a remotemachine.
A is composition of D and E

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **Software Engineering** exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

### **1. Core Topics & Concepts**
#### **A. Software Development Methodologies**
- **Scrum Framework**:
  - **Roles**:
    - **Scrum Master**: Tracks sprint activities, ensures completion.
    - **Product Owner**: Defines backlog priorities.
    - **Development Team**: Executes tasks.
  - **Artifacts**: Sprint Backlog, Product Backlog, Increment.
  - **Events**: Sprint Planning, Daily Standup, Sprint Review, Retrospective.

- **Prototyping**:
  - **Types**:
    - **Storyboards**: Sketches of UI flow.
    - **Paper Prototypes**: Low-fidelity mockups.
    - **Digital Mock-ups**: High-fidelity (e.g., Photoshop/PowerPoint).
    - **Interactive Prototypes**: Clickable wireframes.

#### **B. Software Design Principles**
- **Cohesion Types** (Module Design):
  | Type               | Description                                  |
  |--------------------|----------------------------------------------|
  | **Coincidental**   | Randomly grouped functions.                  |
  | **Procedural**     | Functions execute in sequence.               |
  | **Communicational**| Functions share the same data structure.     |
  | **Sequential**     | Output of one function is input to another.  |

- **Coupling**: Measure of interdependence between modules (avoid tight coupling).

- **Design Patterns**:
  - **Adapter Pattern**: Converts incompatible interfaces (e.g., `HeightConverter` for smartwatch data).
  - **Facade Pattern**: Simplifies complex subsystem interactions.
  - **Strategy Pattern**: Encapsulates interchangeable algorithms.

#### **C. Software Metrics**
- **Code Metrics**:
  | Metric | Definition                          | Example          |
  |--------|-------------------------------------|------------------|
  | **LOC** | Total lines of code.                | `1000`           |
  | **LLOC**| Logical lines of code.              | `800` (excludes comments/blanks) |
  | **SLOC**| Source lines of code.               | `900` (excludes comments) |
  | **Comments** | Number of comment lines.       | `100`            |

- **Cyclomatic Complexity** (McCabe’s Metric):
  - Measures code complexity via independent paths.
  - Formula:
    ```
    V(G) = E − N + 2P
    ```
    - `E` = edges, `N` = nodes, `P` = connected components.
  - **Example**: For the `lsearch` function (Q17), complexity = **2** (paths: `if` + `else`).

#### **D. Testing Techniques**
- **Equivalence Partitioning**:
  - Divide input data into classes (valid/invalid).
  - **Example** (Q23): `computeBonus(income)` test cases:
    - Valid: `{7000, 15000, 150000}` (covers all `if-elif` branches).
    - Invalid: `{-100, 0}`.

- **Coverage Criteria**:
  | Type               | Description                                  | Test Cases (Q25–27)          |
  |--------------------|----------------------------------------------|-------------------------------|
  | **Branch Coverage** | Test all branches (e.g., `if-else`).        | `{-5, 0, 2, 5}`               |
  | **Multiple Condition** | Test all combinations of conditions.    | `{-5, 0, 1, 2, 5}`            |
  | **Path Coverage**  | Test all independent paths.                 | **4 paths** in `fact(n)`.     |

- **Debugging Strategies**:
  - **Forward Strategy**: Trace data flow from trigger to error state.
  - **Backward Strategy**: Reverse from error to root cause.

#### **E. Software Deployment**
- **Environments**:
  | Environment      | Purpose                                  |
  |------------------|------------------------------------------|
  | **Development**  | Local coding/testing.                    |
  | **Testing**      | QA validation.                           |
  | **Staging**      | Pre-production (mirrors production).     |
  | **Production**   | Live user environment.                   |

- **Deployment Strategies**:
  | Strategy          | Description                                  |
  |-------------------|----------------------------------------------|
  | **Blue/Green**    | Switch traffic between identical environments. |
  | **Canary**        | Gradual rollout to a subset of users.       |
  | **Versioned**     | Users choose software versions.             |

#### **F. Requirements Engineering**
- **Techniques**:
  | Technique       | Use Case                                  |
  |-----------------|-------------------------------------------|
  | **Questionnaires** | Large, geographically dispersed users.   |
  | **Interviews**   | In-depth stakeholder insights.            |
  | **Focus Groups** | Collaborative discussion.                |
  | **Documentation**| Existing system analysis.                |

- **SMART User Stories**:
  - **Specific**, **Measurable**, **Achievable**, **Relevant**, **Timeboxed**.
  - **Relevant** = Delivers business value (Q15).

#### **G. UI/UX Heuristics**
- **Nielsen’s Heuristics**:
  - **Prevent Errors**: Disable invalid actions (e.g., booking >3 months in advance).
  - **Error Recovery**: Guide users to correct mistakes.
  - **Help & Documentation**: Provide assistance.

#### **H. Risk Management**
- **Risk Assessment Matrix**:
  | Risk                          | Probability | Impact | Assessed Risk (P × I) |
  |-------------------------------|-------------|--------|-----------------------|
  | Personnel shortfall           | 0.6         | Medium | 0.6                   |
  | **Shortcomings in external components** | **0.2** | **High** | **0.8** (Highest) |
  | Schedule slippage             | 0.3         | High   | 0.9                   |

#### **I. COCOMO Model (Cost Estimation)**
- **Formula**:
  ```
  Effort = a × (LOC)^b  [person-months]
  ```
  - **Organic Project**: `a = 2.4`, `b = 1.05`.
  - **Example** (Q11):
    - `LOC = 3,000,000` → `Effort ≈ 7,966,964.35` person-months.
    - **Staff** = Effort / Duration = `7,966,964.35 / 10 ≈ 796,696` (typo in options; correct: **79,670**).

#### **J. Software Architecture**
- **Peer-to-Peer (P2P)**:
  - Decentralized communication (e.g., music file sharing app).
- **Client-Server**: Centralized (e.g., web apps).
- **MVC**: Separates Model, View, Controller.

#### **K. Class Diagrams (UML)**
- **Relationships**:
  - **Inheritance (Generalization)**: `A → B` (A is a B).
  - **Association**: `B → C` (B uses C).
  - **Composition**: `A ◆ D/E` (A owns D/E; lifetime bound).

---

### **2. Key Equations**
| Concept               | Equation                                  |
|-----------------------|-------------------------------------------|
| **Cyclomatic Complexity** | `V(G) = E − N + 2P`                      |
| **COCOMO Effort**     | `Effort = a × (LOC)^b`                    |
| **Staffing**          | `Staff = Effort / Duration`               |
| **Assessed Risk**     | `Risk = Probability × Impact`             |

---

### **3. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **Graph 1: Software Development Lifecycle**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Requirements] --> B[Design]
    B --> C[Implementation]
    C --> D[Testing]
    D --> E[Deployment]
    E --> F[Maintenance]
    F -->|Feedback| A
    G[Prototyping] -->|Iterative| B
    H[Scrum] -->|Agile| C
```

#### **Graph 2: Testing Techniques**
```mermaid
graph TD
    T[Testing] --> T1[Equivalence Partitioning]
    T --> T2[Branch Coverage]
    T --> T3[Path Coverage]
    T1 -->|Example| TC1["computeBonus(-100, 7000)"]
    T2 -->|Example| TC2["fact(-5, 0, 2)"]
    T3 -->|Independent Paths| TC3["fact(n): 4 paths"]
```

#### **Graph 3: Deployment Environments**
```mermaid
graph LR
    Dev[Development] --> Staging[Staging]
    Staging -->|Mirrors| Prod[Production]
    Testing[Testing] --> Staging
    Prod -->|Live| Users[End Users]
```

#### **Graph 4: Design Principles**
```mermaid
graph TD
    DP[Design Principles] --> Cohesion
    DP --> Coupling
    Cohesion --> C1[Communicational]
    Cohesion --> C2[Sequential]
    Coupling --> Loose[Loose Coupling]
    Coupling --> Tight[Tight Coupling]
    DP --> Patterns
    Patterns --> Adapter["Adapter (e.g., BMI Calculator)"]
    Patterns --> Facade
```

#### **Graph 5: Risk Management**
```mermaid
graph TD
    Risk[Risk Assessment] --> Probability
    Risk --> Impact
    Probability -->|0.2| External[Shortcomings in External Components]
    Impact -->|High| External
    External -->|0.8| Highest[Highest Assessed Risk]
```

---

### **4. Exam Tips**
1. **Focus Areas**:
   - **Scrum roles** (Q3), **prototype types** (Q12), **cohesion** (Q4).
   - **Testing**: Equivalence partitioning (Q23), branch coverage (Q25).
   - **COCOMO calculations** (Q11: check units!).
   - **Class diagrams** (Q24: composition vs. association).
   - **Deployment strategies** (Q10, Q22).

2. **Common Pitfalls**:
   - Misapplying **cyclomatic complexity** (count decision points + 1).
   - Confusing **LLOC/SLOC/LOC** (Q6: match definitions carefully).
   - **COCOMO staffing**: Verify calculations (Q11 answer should be **~79,670**, not 796,696).

3. **Mermaid Syntax Notes**:
   - Avoid LaTeX in graphs; use text labels.
   - Keep graphs simple (max 5–7 nodes per graph).
